It is common for children's speech to be less clear and understandable to adults outside the home, especially if they are not familiar with the child's speech patterns and pronunciation. This is because children often adapt their language to their home environment and the people they interact with regularly.

At home, you are likely more attuned to your child's speech patterns and may be able to understand them more easily because you are accustomed to their way of speaking. However, for people outside the home, it may take some time to adjust to the child's unique speech patterns and understand them more clearly.

There are a few things you can do to help others understand your child better:

1. Encourage your child to speak slowly and clearly. This can help others to hear the individual sounds more clearly and make it easier for them to understand what your child is saying.
2. Ask your child to repeat themselves if someone doesn't understand what they are saying. This can help your child practice their communication skills and give others a chance to hear the words more clearly.
3. Use visual aids like pictures or gestures to help clarify what your child is saying. This can help others to connect the words to the objects or actions they are referring to.
4. Communicate with the adults outside the home about your child's speech patterns and let them know what works best to help them understand. This can help them to better support your child's communication needs.

If you are concerned about your child's speech development, it's always a good idea to consult with a speech-language pathologist who can assess your child's speech and provide targeted strategies to help them improve their communication skills.
